reviewText:
The Gold Egg of the trilogy.

Time travel, parkour, and puzzles. This game does those 3 best. The combat is fairly simple and straightfoward, you can swing your sword, use your dagger, block, jump over enemies, and whatnot.

Puzzles are fairly straightforward and challenging.

And then you have several time altering powers using the Dagger of Time, you have your:

Recall: Reverse time for up to several seconds, usually for saving you from heavy damage, screwing up on a jump or puzzle, or instant deaths.

The Eye of the Storm: Slows down time and makes combat and some puzzles/platforming/parkouring easier.

Enemy Freeze: Renders an enemy frozen in time and much easier to kill.

Frozen Time Assault: Freeze time and go into a badass Omnislash-like frenzy on multiple enemies and wreak havoc.

All time powers require either a sand tank, or a halfmoon depending on which power it is. You fill up sandtanks and halfmoons by finishing enemies with the Dagger of Time.

One of my favorite parts in the game I remember is the bats, who always retreat in groups of 3 when you kill a bunch. My brother would always yell THREE RETREAT!" and I would always laugh.

Man... I wish I would of kept my Gamecube copy of the game I got back in 2003 that my dad got me for Christmas... because... them nostalgias.

The PC version of this game seems to hold up pretty well (at least on XP anyway).

It's a classic game and is pretty badass in general

reviewText:
This game is a true classic, all the way back from a time when ubisoft wasn't a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ tier studio that barfs out half-baked Assassin's Creed clones which run like a nightmare on moderately good hardware. But I digress, the reason why this game is nothing short of awesome is the insanely well executed platforming. In a word... the platforming is just thrilling, its really tight and rewarding despite the sometimes wonky camera. However what makes it a bit of a flawed gem in my opinion is the combat. In theory, and for most part in practice the combat is actually great, way more fun than AC. The main issue I have with the combat is just how when you get knocked down on the ground, which will happen a lot with later enemies that you cant vault over(but you cant help but try to because the vaulting and jumping is the same button but depends on the direction you're pointing towards) its going to be really hard to get back up and so you end dead before you know it, since you'll always have at least 4 enemies constantly hammering you while you're desperately trying to jump back up on your feet. I also wasn't a fan of how each time you kill an enemy a new one spawns out of nowhere to replace it, this padding felt really grindy to me and ended up feeling much more frustrating than challenging so I found myself wanting to get through the otherwise excellent combat to get back to that oh so sweet sweet platforming action. Other than that the gameplay is just perfect. The setting, story, music and the decade+ old graphics all still hold up really well today.
Regarding the technical stuff, you'll need to patch it for high res. support and disable the in game fog option if everything looks grey. I noticed some voice overs skipping and very rarely some weird physics happening @ 144hz, it didn't really detract from the gameplay though. Also It has partial controller support only, so I recommend using xpadder fill in the missing keys that will allow you to save and toggle walk with your controller. Thats it...

Play it/10

reviewText:
A very solid and fun puzzle platformer, re-envisioning the old classic. Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time is one of the most successful revivals in gaming history, and it is well deserved for having done so. The game is a third-person platformer interspersed with action segments featuring melee combat. A time-rewinding mechanic is present to assist both in combat and platforming, which can be recharged by defeating enemies.

The platforming is the focus of the game, and the combat serves more to break up the puzzles - the controls for combat are not as tight as those for platforming, so those sections of the gameplay can be a little less interesting/more frustrating.

The puzzles themselves are rather imaginative, and require some acrobatic moves in order to complete them.

While the graphics are starting to show their age, the game itself holds up. If you enjoy puzzle platformers, you would be doing yourself a disservice by not playing this game.

reviewText:
*Warning* possible spoilers ahead

Pros:
+Excellent platforming based puzzles. These are usually pretty simple to work out once you realise most of them have only one path but when you consider how they work as a whole they are pretty ingenious and will challenge you're platforming skills and timing.

+Great atmosphere and art direction. The Persian setting is unique and rarely done. Even in 2014 this game looks excellent. The character models haven't aged well but the environments have for sure.

+Ability to rewind time and use it in battle is an excellent idea

+First person view allows you to offset the terrible camera

+Varied enemies force you to engage combat in different ways

+The Prince. Although it happens infrequently, when the Prince does chime in it's usually something humorous and entertaining.

Cons:
-The camera is a pain whether you're doing platforming or you're in combat. During platforming the camera will frequently move into undesirable positions forcing you to guess what you're supposed to be doing next. In combat it does the same which quickly becomes tiresome when you're unable to see the enemy attacking you from behind. It also struggles hard when you're in tight spaces and the camera has to contend with walls :S

-You're companion is kinda useless and it feels as if you're partnership is a one way deal. During platforming she will stand there and let you do all the work aside from when she has to go through a few cracks or pull a few triggers (to Ubisoft's credit they use this as a point of humour which is much appreciated). In combat she is the same. The AI refuses to move from a certain position unless you stray too far from her which means that when there are multiple enemies attacking her she is essentially a sitting duck which wouldn't be too bad but she has very low health. Oh and her arrows can harm you. She killed me once when I had one enemy left to kill and a number of times her arrow has hit me stunning me for a number of enemies to take away my remaining health. Her voice actor is also very poor.

-Combat encounters take far too long on occasions. You would expect combat to last about a cpuple of minutes at the most but sometimes they take double that making those encounters tedious to go through.

-Fall heights are deceptive. There are essentially 3 fall heights. Twice you're height which the prince can handle. 2-3 times you're height the Prince will lose a bit of health. Anything above 3 times you're height and the Prince will die. This becomes incredible frustrating when you have what appears to be a manageable fall and yet the prince cant take it. What would have been useful is a more lenient falling system where you took larger damage rather than outright dying for higher drops.

-The story. It feels as though everything is rushed. You never get a chance at the beginning to digest what is actually going and then suddenly you're on this Grand Adventure. What's worse is that at no point aside from the end of the game is the story truly developed, which is a shame because the concept is excellent. There are points in which the subplot with you're companion is expanded but it feels so contrived especially since she is so damn unlikable.

Misc thoughts:

=You're companion would be far more likeable if she was controllable. Frequently during the game there are situations only she can deal with like crawl into narrow spaces etc. I stand by my point that she is still useless as you tend to do 95% of the work but being able to control her would have enabled more complex puzzles and allowed there to be more varied
platforming challenges if creative enough. In combat it would allow you to experience a different combat style and allow you to better position her to reduce damage if you were primarily going to play as the Prince. I belieev this would also help you better engage with her as a character (although thevoice acting is still terrible)

=It would be nice to have a larger variety of sand based abilities to use.

=Controller support on PC would have made the game much more easier to control but as it is it's still very much playable.

Final thought:
Get the game if you enjoy excellent platforming and puzzles but pass if you're buying it for excellent combat or story.

reviewText: The Sands of Time when it originally came out boasted some of the best graphics and fluid 3D animation in games.  By today's standard, the graphics still look great and animation is even more fluid with the advance of video card speed.  The platforming is well executed.  The levels can be massive at times and requires you to go through a maze of wall runs, jumps, and many other acrobatic maneuvers in order to reach your goal.  The game almost runs like each major room is a level and you need to reach its objective/goal in order to move on to the next level.  The action can feel rather repetitive, however, some of the enemies do require a different approach and strategy to take down and kill.  However, the game is well paced to keep the actions repetition from annoying the gameplay too much.  Overall though, the fight scenes are well choreographed and your character looks really cool in action.  The introduction of the Sands of Time and the knife that allows you to rewind time if you fall to your death or get killed in battle is a really cool gimmick that works and fits very well in this game.  The storyline is great, especially when you realize how the beginning and the end come together to completely understand the story.  This is a classic, just as much as the original 2D Prince of Persia is a classic as well.  If you've never played this game, you should do yourself a favor and pick this up and play it.

This was the first computer game I ever owned, besides the pack that came with my dad's Dell and included Total Annhilation, Gex: Enter the Gecko, and Tomb Raider. At the time, its graphics amazed me; the flame seemed so realistic, the landscapes so beautiful. Its graphics are no longer impressive, but its art design is still beautiful, and what I loved about it so much has remained unparalleled in games since: Sands of Time is /beautifully/ written. Its story is moving, its characters are fleshed out with excellent arcs that are both central to and essential in the overall plot, and the unnamed Prince is a charming character.

The puzzles were hard and often frustrating, and the combat was also often difficult, but to this day, Prince of Persia has the best writing I've seen in a video game, and the way the story and the gameplay intertwine is magical to behold.

Buy this game, play this game, and beat this game. You won't regret a second of it.

reviewText:
Prince of Persia is an old game. That much is obvious. However it is more than worth it. The first to bring up the idea of rewinding time to fix your mistakes in parkouring instead of killing you instantly. Like plenty of platforming games of its' time a single mistake would normally send you to a quick death. With the time mechanics of PoP if you have the available resources you can go back and fix those mistakes. The combat is simple yet satisfying when you survive a horde of sand monsters. With a unique health recovery system of drinking water stumbling upon a basin of water or pool is like finding an oasis in the desert. While Prince of Persia is a classic game it has a few problems.

The biggest one is sometimes the controls don't work too well on a mouse and keyboard. With the health system you can go a long time with low health and end up suffering a few frustrating deaths multiple times. There are also a few enemies that are lackluster (crows, scarabs) that get annoying. This is compounded by a short animation that plays of your character putting his weapons away that you can't skip. The last con is that save points have you seeing a vision of a possible future. While it is a neat way of giving you hints there are far too many that are close to each other.

To sum it up Prince of Persia is the start of a good series that hit a home run despite the few problems it has. If you want a classic platformer this is the game for you with crazy contraptions and fun applications of platforming. This game is plenty of fun.

reviewText:
I really wanted to enjoy this game and give it a good review. The Prince of Persia Trilogy are some of my favorite games of all time, and I enjoyed them quite a bit on both PS2 and the original Xbox. Also, PC generally tends to be the most backwards compatible platform out there, and really the place to go to in general for those of us with a bit of a nostalgia kick. I've been able to play the original Doom, the original Diablo, Quest for Glory 1, King's Quest 1 (remake), Dune 2, and countless other older games on my new computer (core i7 with SLI GTX 980s, 32 gb ram, and 5 ssds in a RAID on Windows 10) over the past year with little or no issues.

There are far too many technical issues that ruin the experience here to make it worthwhile though. With having to set up resolutions outside of game to get it to even start to show up on modern monitors, a white out/fog glitch that makes it imposssible to see anything (and I mean anything, the prince, ground, walls, enemies all invisible), no real controller support, and the issues go on. Yes, most of the issues have solutions in the forums, and I probably would have been okay with one or two issues, but that there are so many. I have to go to too many different forum topics and edit ini files to get this game to the start of a playable state, makes it so I just can't recommend this version of it.

If you want to play or replay this game, do yourself a favor and get the PS3 version off Playstation Network. It supports modern resolutions, widescreen, runs smoothly, and even supports active 3d if that's your thing. All with much less work than this version. I feel like if Ubisoft wants to continue selling this on steam, it needs warnigs about it's issues on the store page, or some serious patching love.

Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time is one of the great classics, and it is that for a reason. Aside from the compelling plot and memorable characters, Sands of Time features some of the best puzzle-platforming you'll find in any game. Fluid acrobatics across the rafters of ornate palace rooms and along the sides of immense towers combine with the perfect safety mechanism - the ability to briefly rewind time and undo that disastrous jump or ill-timed leap into a rotating saw blade. The rewind ability is limited in use so that it doesn't become a crutch or make things too easy, but remains effective at helping to curb the frustration that would result from, for instance, a single mistake at the very end of a run of successes. Combined with the brilliant and challenging level design, intuitive controls, and enough hidden secrets to make it worth playing over again, Sands of Time is an extremely satisfying game.

The first game of the new Prince of Persia trilogy, The Sands of Time is an adventure game featuring puzzle-solving and action parts in the spectacular world of Persia. You have to fight your way through a tumble-down, but royal persian castle and discover the more ancient civilizations it covers. The gameplay not as ordinary as it sounds first; you can kill your enemies in many ways, using the acrobatic skills of the prince and the environment. You can even manipulate time. And if it's not enough there is an other survivor out there: the beatiful princess, Farah.\n\nPrince of Persia: The Sands of Time is a game of fight, action, puzzle solving and acrobatics with a dazing storyline of love and treason. Coming with a pretty charming soundtrack, it's one of the best games of all times.

which sure does suck whenever your  only real way of getting out of that situation is jumping over enemies, and the type of enemy surrounding you are ones that can't be jumped over.

The game is also far too simple, partly because of one major sin: automatic lock-on. If you are even pointing your analog stick in the directon of the enemy, you'll magically be attracted to that enemy for a while, even if you're pointing away from them. It's really annoying, and can lead to many times of getting surrounded. Trying to roll through a tight gap to avoid getting surrounded by un-jumpable enemies? Too bad; you're jumping on the un-jumpable enemy. Trying to attack a once faraway enemy that you're getting closer to? You will if you get lucky enough that the Prince stops ogling at an enemy you were attacking prior. Even beyond the frustrating bits with the controls, there's the fact that every single enemy is defeated in the same way: attack until they fall on their stomach, use the dagger to absorb them. Also yes, if you were wondering, the lock-on can mess you up with this as well, leading you to use powerups on enemies you didn't want to when you were just trying to absorb some sand.

And then there's your game-long escort, Farah. Notice how I said escort and not partner? Intentional. She's an absolute idiot in combat. She comes with a bow, but constantly insists on standing statuesque directly in the fray, even when being attacked, when a much simpler solution would be for her to get to some dang high ground. There's loads of it around, so there's really no excuse for it. Also, if she dies, the game is over. What does she offer to the game as a whole? The ability to crawl through small gaps. Yes, in the grand scheme of things, she's about as useful as a puppy, mouse, or other small animal. She's about as useful in combat as well, actually. You see, she can't actually kill enemies. She just stuns them every now and then when she's not looking around in random directions admiring the architecture as though the idea of stone buildings is the most amazing thing ever. Long story short, she's absolutely useless and is more of a liablility than anything else.

Speaking of the architecture (and something positive), the level design is fantastic. I'll go more into detail in the graphics section, but for now, I can definitely say that they did an excellent job creating a world that feels natural for the most part. There are a few pretty contrived places here and there, but who knows what those crazy architects are up to anymore, eh? Apart from that, though, that's all I really have to say about this game's gameplay. The platforming is super fun, but the combat just really brings the game down in my opinion. Then again, maybe games like Metal Gear Rising, Bayonetta, and Devil May Cry 1 have led me to expect too much from these kinds of games. I still stand with what I said at the beginning; this game would be so much better if it were two games: a game focused almost entirely on platforming with maybe 5% of the game being combat, and another game being 95% combat (with a more-developed combat system/enemy variety) and 5% platforming. As is, you've got one really good thing and one really frustrating thing which kinda makes me not wanna play this game again. If it weren't for the combat, this game would easily get a 10/10 from me, but with the combat, it drops to a 7/10. Great at times; absolutely miserable at others.

Story: You may have gathered from that one paragraph that I don't like Farah all that much. You'd be right. To be honest, it still doesn't really make sense why she comes along at all; she's useful for being small and that's about it. All this being said though, she's not a badly written character; just an okay one. She is a love interest of the Prince, which again feels pretty contrived to me, and to be quite frank; I think the Prince is insane for wanting her. Oh well; I couldn't possibly hope to understand what goes through the Prince's head. As for the prince itself, he's pretty much straddling the line between hero and anti-hero. He wants to do good, but he's a bit of a selfish prat at the same time. Then again, he *is* a prince, so you can't expect him to have had the greatest socialization experience growing up, so fair enough. Apart from Farah and the Prince, everyone else is just a minor character. The premise and delivery is pretty cool, too; it's being told in terms of a story, and as such, has the ablility to go back and forth, as does happen with the story and the gameplay. It's all quite clever, I must admit. While the character arcs may not be the most amazing thing ever, I can appreciate the clever nature of the delivery and the premise enough to give it an 8/10.

The Sands of Time is a magnificent emulation of the Tales of the Arabian Nights, told with dated but functional tech.

The story is what to come for here. It is masterfully told, and was one of the first games I remember to really embrace the unique medium of video games. Whether it's the Prince's narration during the pause screen, or the moment you realize exactly how the main menu fits into the plot. The Sands of Time stands apart as a true masterpiece of video game storytelling.

The platforming, parkour gameplay, which eventually inspired Assassin's Creed, was surprisingly polished and fluid for the time. Gamers that have grown accustomed to more modern games may find it a bit simple, but gamers that remember the many headaches of 3D platforming on N64 will appreciate the ability to execute leaps and ledge grabs with precision. This game was clearly designed for analogue stick movement however; having to use WASD to move is a travisty.

The combat has always been the low point of this game. At best, it's a tedious, repetive affair, forcing you to learn the exact combination of acrobatic and combat skills to bring an enemy down easiest, and repeat that over, and over, and over, and over, and over again. At worst the combat is downright broken. The camera has tremendous difficulty keeping the Prince's schitzophrenic auto targeted foes in frame while bouncing off walls and around pillars. The Prince himself seems utterly unable to avoid striking the wrong target. A noteworthy design flaw is the fact that you can only block/parry when you are focused on an enemy, but you only focus on the last enemy that hit you, and it's rare for the same enemy to attack twice in a row.

Even with the poor controls, camera issues, and tedious combat, The Sands of Time is worth playing for anyone interested in pushing video games as a valid storytelling medium. It shines even among modern games as the standard for story quality while making the telling an accomplishment that couldn't be done in any other medium.

Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time is one of the great classics, and it is that for a reason. Aside from the compelling plot and memorable characters, Sands of Time features some of the best puzzle-platforming you'll find in any game. Fluid acrobatics across the rafters of ornate palace rooms and along the sides of immense towers combine with the perfect safety mechanism - the ability to briefly rewind time and undo that disastrous jump or ill-timed leap into a rotating saw blade. The rewind ability is limited in use so that it doesn't become a crutch or make things too easy, but remains effective at helping to curb the frustration that would result from, for instance, a single mistake at the very end of a run of successes. Combined with the brilliant and challenging level design, intuitive controls, and enough hidden secrets to make it worth playing over again, Sands of Time is an extremely satisfying game.

Just to make one thing very clear right from the start: This game was one of my first full 3d games (besides Prince of Persia 3d, actually, but well, we all know how that game looked), and actually was one of my first very own games. Got it for my 8th birthday, and it took me forever to finish it because I was really bad at games and was scared of the sand monsters. Naturally, with a history like this, I am deeply, DEEPLY biased towards this game, so you should probably take my review of it with a huuuuuuge grain of salt.

Well, with that out of the way, let's begin, eh?

Just some fyi history for those interested:

This game is actually the fourth in a series that started back in 1989. The original game was a 2d sidescrolling-ish platformer-ish based entirely of (for its time) realistic movement and 1v1 sword duels. It was a pretty big success, and it spawned two sequels. The first one was just like the original in design, just better looking, longer and more cryptic. I haven't beaten it without cheats to this day, and especially the last level is very unintuitive, though also very memorable.
Sadly, the third game was made in a time where EVERYTHING had to go 3d. Though originally intended as a 2d game just like its predecessors, it was ground through the 3d meatwolf. Though I personally loved it, it wasn't a big success (understandably so), and the series went dead for a few years. Eventually, Ubisoft got the rights, and with the help of the original developer Jordan Mechner, they created a new Prince of Persia game, with a new character, and a semi-new setting (it's still Persia obviously, just somewhere else in Persia).
So what's the story? A young persian prince is riding with his dad, the king of Persia, to conquer and raid an indian palace. With the help of a traitor on the inside (an evil vizier, what a shocker), they get through the gates and storm the palace. The prince gets into the (unrealistically huge) treasure chamber, where two mysterious and powerful artifacts are housed: The hourglass, and the dagger of time. The prince claims the dagger for himself, and the persian army moves on to the kingdom of Azhat (Azat? Ahza... I don't even know if it's a real place, something like that anyway), where the evil vizier tricks the prince into ramming the dagger into the hourglass. That wasn't such a great idea, as it turns out, as the magical sand blasts out of the hourglass, ruining the palace and corrupting all living things inside, turning them into immortal zombies. No matter how many times you strike them down, they just pop back up. Unless the prince rams his dagger into their bellies and sucks the sand out of them, then they die for good. So now it's on: the prince and Farah, the daughter of the indian Maharaja, team up to fix the terrible mess that was caused.
You spend a lot of time around Farah actually, and she is a very great character to be around. Helping you out in battle with her bow and arrow, crawling though creaks too small for the bulky prince, helping him solve puzzles, and being an allaround believable and likable character. She's one of the few companion characters done right, and I say that even though you sometimes have to protect her during battle, which is, as we are all aware, the worst thing in gaming.
The game builds a very nice atmosphere too; it's just you and Farah in a ruined, but still beautiful world. Moonlit gardens, waterfilled caverns with flickering reflections, great halls and massive towers; the architectural design is as unbelievable as it can get, but it never takes you out of the moment since the game oviously has no pretends of being realistic; it's a fairy tale, 1001 night with time zombies, and even to this day, it's a beautiful looking game.
Gameplay is pretty fun, though the games following after it improved on the combat, it's still very solid. You swing your sword, you block, you counter, you can do some fancy jump maneuvers over enemies heads and off of walls. Most uniquely though, you can wind back time for a bit using your dagger, That technique is equally useful during combat as it is during platforming. You don't have to start back at the checkpoint every single time you die that way, which is really nice. Also, you can slow down time during combat, or freeze an enemy in place and then chop it to dust; ooor you can unleash a very strange finishing move where all the enemies get frozen and you zhip around between them, chopping em all up. It's nothing too special, but it's entertaining nonetheless.
So that's about all I can say about the game without giving the story away. As it stands, the only real problem I have with the steam release is that the ingame steam overlay doesn't work. But here's the strangest part: when I installed the game off the old disc version I still had lying around, and added it as a non-steam game, the overlay worked fine. What's up with that? I would've just stuck with that technique, but then I had to leave the disc in the drive the entire time, which is annoying. So I don't know what's up with that bug; it's not too bad, but I wish it wasn't there.

TL;DR
Pros:
-great story
-amazing fairytale-esque atmosphere
-likable and unforgettable characters
-goodcontrols
-solid and fun gameplay and combat
-rewind mechanic makes platforming a lot less frustrating
-the game still looks beautiful to this day

Cons:
-steam overlay doesn't work ingame for no real reason

Nostalgia overload/10

This is my favourite POP game. I love the story, characters and level design.
I'm not a big fan of third person hack&slash combat so the fact that around 50% of this game IS combat is a bit of a drawback for me but nevertheless, I still love the game overall.
The game does have controller support but not in the menus. I preferred to use Xpadder to map my controls. This not only allowed me to navigate the menus with a controller but also allowed me to put a rumble on sword attacks. If you have Pinnacle or the Xpadder programs and want to play the game on your sofa through Big Picture I suggest you do the same.
I played this game on Windows 10 and I've found the experience extremely frustrating at times due to a plethora of bugs.
There is a bug that stops the Prince from running, a bug that makes the screen foggy so that you can't see what is happening, numerous camera angle burps that prevent the player from seeing what is going on in combat, and last but not least, an issue with the physics. Sometimes the Prince will get stuck on scenery, other times the boxes you occasionally have to push around go flying across the screen and get lodged on steps. (This last bug took me over an hour to circumnavigate using crafty bug exploits of my own)
It is my belief that if a game is on sale on Steam then it should run properly on modern computer equipment.

If this game was bug-free I would give it a well deserved 9/10
As it stands at the time of writing this review and in relation to the bugs I'm forced to give it a 4/10

Most of the bugs can and have been worked around by the community, and I was able to complete the game with a lot of patience.

A real shame Valve doesn't hold these publishers to account. How can it be right to release buggy games to consumers? If a game is going to be placed on the Steam store front then its publishers should put forth a little effort to make sure it runs correctly.

Surprisingly enough in this day and age the king of the early 2000s generation of games has aged quite decently, decently enough to be considerably better than other (probably most) 3D platformers currently out in the market. Price of Persia: The Sands of Time has a completely different formula from many other games you will play, it is still difficult to find games with new mechanics as intuitive as the time mechanics in this game back when it introduced them. It made platforming and puzzles funner despite being brutal without this mechanic, and the story created around this mechanic is absolutely amazing. The setpieces set in ancient Persia are absolutely gorgeous, and you are going to climb through all of them, even the furthest mighty tower is a tower you will platform through and feel like an absolute badass. Not only that, but you actually have a legitimate reason within the story to be going through all these setpieces, having a naive yet skillful prince grow as his journey continues with probably the best supporting character ever, who has one of the funniest yet completely natural relationships with our heroic prince. It all feels organic, you feel like a badass and you have all the right to. The only bits where the game manages to dwindle on it's greatness are a few bits of combat that drag out for way too long, but even then, it is most likely followed by an amazing platforming section and story bit that will make you forget it completely. This game was a legend and still is, buy it, at any given price buy it, because I can guarantee that you will never have such an amazing experience that feels new and interesting as you will with this marvel.
